VOL. XXXI, No. 23

JAY HARRIERS WIN
SOUTH ATLANTICS
Five Hopkins Runners Finish in First
Nine

GWINN TAKES SECOND
Victory at Washington Tops Perfect
Season

Battling a fierce cold and a field
of twenty-four runners, the Johns
Hopkins cross country team easily
won the South Atlantic Championship at Washington, Saturday. Five
of the first men to finish were wearers of the blue.
Gwinn Leads

•

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 21, 1926

DR. WHITEHEAD TO
LECTURE IN FRANCE
Dr. John Boswell Whitehead, Dean of the School of
Engineering at this university,
will sail from New York on
December 27 for an extended
tour of France as Exchange
Professor of Engineering and
Applied Science. He has prepared a series of nine lectures
on "Dielectric Theory and Insulation," which he will deliver at most of the foremost
technical schools of the French
Republic. Dr. Whitehead's
leave of absence extends from
January 1 (1927) to October
1 (1927).
No Exchange Professor is
coming to the United ; States
from France in 1927, but there
probably will be one selected
for the following year.

SWIM MEET PENDING WITH
MASSACHUSETTS TECH
AT BOSTON
Coach Hill Hopes to Develop Winning
Combination from Raw Material; No
Time Trials Before Holidays

Massachusetts School of Technology at Boston is a possible opponent for the Jay swimmers on
Friday, March 18. Negotiations
have been started to schedule
the Beantown College on the day
following the Brown University
meet at Providence.

Regarding the.possibilities for a
winning team, Eddie Hill, coach
of the Hopkins swimmers, states
that although there are few outstanding individual stars on the
squad, by means of strenuous
training, he hopes to wield the
raw material into a winning outfit.
Hill believes that with constant

It seems that a few of the readers of Pourboire have the perverted idea that the "aimless chatterings," "bits of nothing," "banal
mouthings" or what have you expressed in this column convey the
views of the NEWS-LETTER.
We ask all fair readers to realize
that all opinions expressed in Pourboire are only an impersonal ones
and that the thoughts expressed in
this column have nothing to do with
those of the NEWS-LETTER. For
the views of this paper we refer
you to the editorials.
We here wish to make a sincere
apology to the editor, to whose
kindness the survival of Pourboire
is due and we hope that no harm
has been done.

MILITARISM ABSENT FROM
NEW GERMANY, SAYS
DR. JACKH

Humorist To lecture
DORM DOINGS

Government Now Under Leadership of
German People Instead of
Army Leaders

"German democracy means not
also a new mentality," said Dr.
only a new political system, but
Earnst Jackh, president of the Institute of Political Science, at Berlin, in his lecture Thursday evening on "The New Germany." Dr.
J ackh is also president of the German League of Nations Union,
and has served on the most itnportant German commissions
since the war.
Dr. Jackh briefly discussed political conditions under the empire. Under the old constitution,
which Kaiser Frederick called
"An artificial chaos," there was
much separation and independence of the various branches of
the government, a condition which
brought about the control of the
administration by the military
powers. In this manner Prussia
obtained the ascendancy, and imposed militarism on the rest of
Germany.
"The real revolution,- Dr.
Jackh pointed out,"took place not
in November, but in October." It
was thei that the government was
organized into a monarchy, only
in name, a democracy like England. The revolution of November was the rising of the masses
against the rigors of the war.
First the monarchy went and then
the military.
"Hindenberg," Dr. Jackh said,
"is like George Washington, always working for his country; he
is the leader in peace as well as in
war." He, together with Ebert,
has done great good for the German republic. Ebert was the man
to deal with the laboring classes,
Hindenberg, the bourgeoisie. Dr.
Jackh called to mind the fact that
it was Hindenberg who advised
the emperor to leave the country,
and that it is he, who is trying
more than any other to further
peace in the world.
The New Germany, as Dr.
Jackh explained, is under the control of the entire people. The govContinued on Page 3, Col. 4

The entertainment committee is
well pleased with the financial returns from the dance. In fact, they
were sufficient to warrant another
dormitory dance sometime after
mid-year examinations. This is the
first committee of the new Board
of Governors which has actually
done some real work.
The dance broke up promptly at
one o'clock and most of the crowd
departed immediately. Every resident at the dance hopes that the
evening's merriment did not interfere with the work or comfort of
those residents not at the dance.

SOUTH ATLANTICS
Five Hopkins Runners Finish in First
Nine

GWINN TAKES SECOND
Victory at Washington Tops Perfect
Season

Battling a fierce cold and a field
of twenty-four runners, the Johns
Hopkins cross country team easily
won the South Atlantic Championship at Washington, Saturday. Five
of the first men to finish were wearers of the blue.
Gwinn Leads

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 21, 1926

DR. WHITEHEAD TO
LECTURE IN FRANCE
Dr. John Boswell Whitehead, Dean of the School of
Engineering at this university,
will sail from New York on
December 27 for an extended
tour of France as Exchange
Professor of Engineering and
Applied Science. He has prepared a series of nine lectures
on "Dielectric Theory and Insulation," which he will deliver at most of the foremost
technical schools of the French
Republic. Dr. Whitehead's
leave of absence extends from
January 1 (1927) to October
1 (1927).
No Exchange Professor is
coming to the United ; States
from France in 1927, but there
probably will be one selected
for the following year.

SWIM MEET PENDING WITH
MASSACHUSETTS TECH
AT BOSTON
Coach Hill Hopes to Develop Winning
Combination from Raw Material; No
Time Trials Before Holidays

Massachusetts School of Technology at Boston is a possible opponent for the Jay swimmers on
Friday, March 18. Negotiations
have been started to schedule
the Beantown College on the day
following the Brown University
meet at Providence.

Regarding the.possibilities for a
winning team, Eddie Hill, coach
of the Hopkins swimmers, states
that although there are few outstanding individual stars on the
squad, by means of strenuous
training, he hopes to wield the
raw material into a winning outfit.

MILITARISM ABSENT FROM
NEW GERMANY, SAYS
DR. JACKH

Humorist To lecture
DORM DOINGS

Government Now Under Leadership of
German People Instead of
Army Leaders

"German democracy means not
also a new mentality," said Dr.
only a new political system, but
Earnst Jackh, president of the Institute of Political Science, at Berlin, in his lecture Thursday evening on "The New Germany." Dr.
J ackh is also president of the German League of Nations Union,
and has served on the most itnportant German commissions
since the war.
Dr. Jackh briefly discussed political conditions under the empire. Under the old constitution,
which Kaiser Frederick called
"An artificial chaos," there was
much separation and independence of the various branches of
the government, a condition which
brought about the control of the
administration by the military
powers. In this manner Prussia
obtained the ascendancy, and imposed militarism on the rest of
Germany.
"The real revolution,- Dr.
Jackh pointed out,"took place not
in November, but in October." It
was thei that the government was
organized into a monarchy, only
in name, a democracy like England. The revolution of November was the rising of the masses
against the rigors of the war.
First the monarchy went and then
the military.
"Hindenberg," Dr. Jackh said,
"is like George Washington, always working for his country; he
is the leader in peace as well as in
war." He, together with Ebert,
has done great good for the German republic. Ebert was the man
to deal with the laboring classes,
Hindenberg, the bourgeoisie. Dr.
Jackh called to mind the fact that
it was Hindenberg who advised
the emperor to leave the country,
and that it is he, who is trying
more than any other to further
peace in the world.
The New Germany, as Dr.
Jackh explained, is under the control of the entire people. The govContinued on Page 3, Col. 4

The entertainment committee is
well pleased with the financial returns from the dance. In fact, they
were sufficient to warrant another
dormitory dance sometime after
mid-year examinations. This is the
first committee of the new Board
of Governors which has actually
done some real work.
The dance broke up promptly at
one o'clock and most of the crowd
departed immediately. Every resident at the dance hopes that the
evening's merriment did not interfere with the work or comfort of
those residents not at the dance.
